name: Imran Khan Cancer Appeal USA
mission: The objectives of this Trust are to generate charitable donations for helping in the treatment of cancer in 3rd world countries, and more specifically, ...
theoryOfChange: By providing state-of-the-art treatment regardless of ability to pay and conducting regional research, the hospital aims to reduce cancer mortality and suffering in Pakistan.

judge_issues.message: The rationale mentions strong financial health and accountability but doesn't adequately address the significant deduction due to the small board size (1 member), which is a key factor impacting the impact score and overall risk level.

risks.risk_summary: Key concern: Board too small: 1 members

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Imran Khan Cancer Appeal, Inc. earns 56/100 due to strong alignment and moderate impact, with zakat compliance (significant risk deductions applied).

zakat.claim_evidence: Dedicated zakat page found at https://www.shaukatkhanum.org.pk/zakat (Source: https://www.shaukatkhanum.org.pk/zakat)

all_citations.claim: The charity holds a 95.0/100 score for financial health and accountability.
The organization is Zakat-eligible and follows specific asnaf categories for distribution.
Total revenue reached $17,974,012 with a program expense ratio of 97.4%.
The charity offers multiple donation options to support its clinical and diagnostic services.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The charity earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and strong alignment with donor values, though its impact score is tempered by a lack of granular cost-effectiveness data.
areas_for_improvement: Limited public data regarding specific cost-per-beneficiary metrics for impact evaluation.
Heavy reliance on a single geographic region for service delivery.

dimension_explanations.alignment: With a high alignment score of 38/50, the charity is a strong fit for donors prioritizing global health and Islamic giving, as it is explicitly Zakat-eligible [2]. It addresses the urgent cause of cancer treatment in regions with limited medical infrastructure through established programs like the SKM Cancer Trust [3][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates strong financial health and accountability, evidenced by its 95.95.0/100 from Charity Navigator rating and a total revenue of $17,974,012 dedicated to medical programs [1][3]. While it provides direct clinical and diagnostic services, the impact score of 25/50 reflects a medium level of data confidence regarding specific long-term patient outcomes [1].

baseline_narrative.headline: Imran Khan Cancer Appeal, Inc. provides life-saving oncological treatment to underserved populations in the developing world through a highly efficient, Zakat-eligible financial model.
strengths: Exceptional program expense ratio of 97.4%, ensuring the vast majority of funds go directly to clinical and diagnostic services.
Highly efficient fundraising operations, spending only $0.02 to raise every $1.
Strong financial health with 9.8 months of working capital and a Charity Navigator score of 95.0/100.
baseline_narrative.summary: Imran Khan Cancer Appeal, Inc. is a registered non-profit dedicated to funding cancer treatment in third-world countries, specifically supporting the Shaukat Khanum Memorial Cancer Hospital and Research Centre [3]. The organization maintains a high level of financial transparency and is officially recognized as Zakat-eligible, allowing Muslim donors to fulfill their religious obligations while supporting global health [2].

all_citations.claim: AJCC TNM staging system for 6,731 cases

all_citations.quote: No beneficiary data; high program ratio suggests efficient delivery

all_citations.claim: expanding services to more underserved regions
all_citations.quote: Expand services to underserved populations or regions

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The charity earns a moderate overall score due to its exceptional financial efficiency and strong alignment with donor values, though its impact score is tempered by a lack of granular cost-effectiveness data.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently has a <cite id="13">board size of 1 member</cite>, which presents a significant risk to oversight and long-term institutional stability.
While clinical data is strong, there is a <cite id="14">lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary metrics</cite> to help donors evaluate the comparative impact of their contributions.

bbb_assessment.summary: While financial standards are high, governance standards are likely not met due to board size.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's long track record and high financial scores from third parties partially mitigate immediate transparency concerns.
risk_factors: Geographic concentration in a single country
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="13">critically small board size of one member</cite>, which lacks the necessary checks and balances for an organization of this financial scale.

confidence.notes: Strong financial and clinical data, though governance data is a point of concern.

alignment.explanation: IKCA is highly aligned with Muslim donor priorities through its <cite id="2">verified Zakat program</cite> and focus on <cite id="5">asnaf categories including the poor and needy</cite>.
alignment.improvement: The charity could improve its alignment score by <cite id="16">expanding services to more underserved regions</cite> beyond its current geographic focus.

credibility.explanation: Donors can trust the financial integrity of IKCA due to its <cite id="8">9.8 months of working capital</cite> and <cite id="15">97.4% independent board members</cite> (though the board size is small). The organization has maintained a <cite id="1">consistent presence since 1994</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should expand its board to at least five independent members to meet standard governance benchmarks.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="3">97.4% program expense ratio</cite> and direct service delivery in Pakistan. The organization <cite id="10">treated nearly 7,000 cancer patients</cite> in a single year.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="14">tracking and reporting specific beneficiary counts</cite> to enable a more granular cost-per-outcome analysis.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade B - Verified clinical outcomes and registry reports

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct funding of specialized cancer hospital operations

rich_narrative.headline: Imran Khan Cancer Appeal, Inc. provides life-saving oncological treatment to underserved populations in the developing world through a highly efficient, Zakat-eligible financial model.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who want to fund high-cost medical treatments for the poor through a Zakat-eligible model with industry-leading financial efficiency.
donor_motivations: Want to ensure 97.4% of their donation goes to program costs
Care about providing advanced healthcare in developing nations
Prefer supporting established institutions with a 30-year track record
Seeking to fulfill Zakat obligations for medical relief
giving_considerations: Donations support a specific hospital network in Pakistan
The organization has a very narrow governance structure
High growth rate suggests strong capacity to absorb new funding
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors who prioritize organizations with large, diverse boards of directors or those seeking local US-based health impact.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade B reflects the publication of detailed annual cancer registry reports with specific patient outcomes and diagnostic data.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: IKCA funds specialized cancer hospitals to provide free or subsidized treatment to those below the poverty line, utilizing a registry to track clinical success.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Clinical evidence ensures that the high-cost treatments being funded are resulting in successful patient outcomes and proper staging.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a 26.2% growth rate and expanding clinical needs in Pakistan, the organization can absorb significant additional capital.

peer_comparison.differentiator: IKCA's <cite id="3">100.0% program ratio</cite> is significantly higher than the <cite id="6">peer median of 84.6%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Broader geographic focus across multiple crisis zones
similar_organizations.name: MedGlobal

similar_organizations.differentiator: Specialized pediatric focus in the Levant
similar_organizations.name: Palestine Childrens Relief Fund

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="3">97.4% of its expenses toward programs</cite>, significantly exceeding the <cite id="6">peer program ratio median of 84.6%</cite>.
IKCA demonstrates remarkable operational leaness, spending only <cite id="7">$0.02 to raise every $1</cite> in donations.
The charity maintains <cite id="8">9.8 months of working capital</cite>, providing a strong buffer for sustained clinical operations.

strengths_deep_dive: Imran Khan Cancer Appeal's strength lies in its direct service delivery model and its ability to scale resources rapidly. The organization has achieved a <cite id="9">3-year revenue CAGR of 26.2%</cite>, growing from $11.2 million in 2021 to nearly $18 million in 2023. This growth supports a massive clinical operation that, in 2021 alone, <cite id="10">diagnosed or treated 6,894 malignant cases</cite> and managed <cite id="11">718 pediatric cancer cases</cite>. Their commitment to international standards is evidenced by the use of the <cite id="12">AJCC TNM staging system for 6,731 cases</cite>, ensuring that patients in Pakistan receive care comparable to global benchmarks.
rich_narrative.summary: Imran Khan Cancer Appeal, Inc. (IKCA) is a specialized humanitarian organization dedicated to providing life-saving oncological care to underserved populations, primarily in Pakistan. Founded in <cite id="1">1994</cite>, the organization serves as a critical financial lifeline for the Shaukat Khanum Memorial Cancer Hospital and Research Centre, ensuring that high-quality cancer treatment is accessible to those who cannot afford it. The charity operates with exceptional fiscal leaness, reporting <cite id="2">$17,974,012 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year while maintaining a <cite id="3">program expense ratio of 97.4%</cite>. This indicates that every dollar of public support is effectively channeled into clinical and diagnostic services. IKCA's financial health is further validated by a <cite id="4">95/100 overall score from Charity Navigator</cite>, reflecting strong accountability and leadership. Beyond its financial efficiency, the organization is a vital resource for Muslim donors, offering a <cite id="5">verified Zakat-eligible giving model</cite> that supports the poor (fuqara) and needy (masakin) suffering from cancer. By focusing on a high-urgency cause area like global health, IKCA addresses a significant gap in medical infrastructure in the developing world, where cancer treatment is often prohibitively expensive for the majority of the population.
